quoteLast: Beatty sights High Seas Fleet, and turns north (column right about).
title: A True Account of the Battle of Jutland, May 31, 1916
author: Frothingham, Thomas Goddard, 1865-1945

quoteFirst: The Naval Brigade of 80 men were armed also with deadly rockets, especially calculated to create a panic among such troops as the Abyssinians.  The greater part of the day had passed, and Sir Robert had no intention of commencing an action, when, at
quoteTime: forty-two minutes past four in the afternoon
quoteLast: of the 10th of April, a gun was fired from the crest of Fala, 1200 feet above the Arogye plain.  A few rounds followed, plunging into the ground close to the British, when several thousand men, the flower of Theodore's army, rushed impetuously over the crest of the hill down the precipitous slopes, yelling defiance, led by their chiefs on sure-footed Galla ponies.
title: Our Soldiers: Gallant Deeds of the British Army during Victoria's Reign
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

title: A thousand miles on an elephant in the Shan States

quoteFirst: (4) Kanôpos or Aboukir.—A train leaves the Ramleh station at Alexandria at 7.40 A.M., and reaches Aboukir at 10.42 A.M., returning from Aboukir at
quoteLast: It is a short walk northwards from the station to the temple of Zephyrion discovered by Daninos Pasha in 1891. Then walk eastward along the shore, where the rocks have been cut into baths and numerous relics of antiquity lie half-covered by the waves.
title: The Egypt of the Hebrews and Herodotos
author: Sayce, A. H. (Archibald Henry), 1845-1933

quoteFirst: Lessens his diameter two seconds, and makes a retrograde motion of 2° 56´. On 27th, at 9:57 a. m., is 4° 40´ north of the moon. He rises on the 1st at
quoteLast: and sets on the 2d at 6:07 a. m.; rises on the 16th at 3:35 p. m. and sets on the 17th at 5:09 a. m.; rises on the 30th at 2:34 p. m. and sets on the 31st at 4:10 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, March 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: “At 4.38 P.M. _Southampton_ reported the enemy’s Battle Fleet ahead. The destroyers were recalled, and at
quoteLast: the enemy’s Battle Fleet was sighted S.E. Course was altered 16 points in succession to starboard, and I proceeded on a northerly course to lead them towards the Grand Fleet.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: Doughty and Sergeant Reeves, of the Forty-eighth, who nobly volunteered to go into the mine to ascertain the cause of failure to explode. The break in the fuse was found and relighted. At
quoteLast: we witnessed a volcano and experienced an earthquake. With a tremendous burst, which shook the hills around, a column of earth shot upwards to an enormous height, bearing the "Elliot salient," its guns and garrison, and making a crater or chasm one hundred and thirty-five feet long, ninety-seven feet wide, and more than thirty feet deep.
title: History of the Thirty-sixth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers. 1862-1865
author: Burrage, Henry S. (Henry Sweetser), 1837-1926; Hodgkins, William H. (William Henry), 1840-1905; Noyes, Edmund W.; Ranlett, S. Alonzo; White, Alonzo A.
